title: China Eximbank provides a 239.3 million USD loan for reconstruction of MaryAzot Production Association plant (Linked to Project ID#69498, #40330)
description: On August 22, 2006, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a 300 million USD preferential export buyer's credit framework agreement with the Government of Turkmenistan, which is captured in project ID#40330). The loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an annual interest rate of 3.0%.On January 27, 2007, CITIC International Cooperation Corporation and Turkey National Fertilizer Co., Ltd. signed the contract for the construction and renovation of the MaryAzot Production Association plant under the 3 billion U.S. dollars referential export buyer's credit framework.Then, on November 3-4, 2007, China and Turkmenistan signed for two subsidiary loans with the same terms as the framework agreement: a loan of 60,642,000 USD was allocated for the construction of the Ashgabat Glass Factory, a glass-manufacturing plant (captured by linked project ID#69498) and a loan of 239,358,000 USD for the construction of new facilities and reconstruction of MaryAzot Production Association (captured by this project). To secure these loans, the Central Bank of Turkmenistan agreed to deposit $50 million USD from the State Fund for Development of the Oil and Gas Industry and Mineral Resources of Turkmenistan.The project consisted of a reconstruction of the MaryAzot Production Association and the construction of a carbamide plant with a planned capacity of 400,000 tons in the town of Mary. China Eximbank's loan constituted 90% of the financing necessary for the 266 million USD reconstruction project, while Turkmendokun joint-stock company covered the remaining 10%. CITIC International was responsible for implementing the project.STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 马雷氮肥厂新建和改造项目.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=LBA0000020071108e3b5001o0&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.chem.hc360.com/2007/02/0514555186.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=TRENDE0020070129e31t001ry&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=DLSTEN0020071109e3b50000a&cat=a&ep=ASI, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.cetin.net.cn/cetin2/servlet/cetin/action/HtmlDocumentAction;jsessionid=4FC102D37704901FF631F5521FDB8388?baseid=1&docno=309802, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=BBCCA00020071211e3cb001md&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=NOVA000020060824e28o0002y&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://web.archive.org/web/20180818125242/http://www.cccme.org.cn/products/detail-8041102.aspx, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.turkmenistan.ru/en/node/4898, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://search.proquest.com/openview/53ca9317b57c93128c829652dca73dad/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=43636, Academic Journal Article; https://www.dropbox.com/s/77e5y0ofv1zfphk/%E5%9C%9F%E5%BA%93%E6%9B%BC%E6%96%AF%E5%9D%A6--%E4%B8%AD%E5%9B%BD%E5%AF%B9%E5%A4%96%E5%BC%80%E6%94%BE30%E5%91%A8%E5%B9%B4%E5%9B%9E%E9%A1%BE%E5%B1%95.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/c0so9pwet0v5tnt/Turkmenistan%20-%20Retrospective%20of%20the%2030th%20Anniversary%20of%20China%27s%20Opening%20to%20the%20Outside%20World.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: CNPC Amu Darya provides scholarships for 133 Turkmen students to study at China University of Petroleum since 2008
description: Since 2008, Amu Darya River Gas Company of China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) has sponsored the higher education of 133 Turkmen high school students at the China University of Petroleum - Beijing (CUPB). In their first year of study abroad, the students study Chinese. After they pass the necessary examinations, the students then decide to study either petroleum engineering, chemical technology, geology, or another major. After four years of coursework, they receive their bachelor's degree. 76 of the students who received the scholarship went to work in the oil and gas industry after their studies, while 57 students were studying at China University of Petroleum in July 2019. In 2019, ten Turkmen high school graduates received the scholarship. STAFF_NOTE: 2008 was coded as the commitment year because these scholarships began that year; however, 'Year uncertain' box was checked because it is not confirmed that CNPC committed to these scholarships in that. Amu Darya River Gas Company of China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC), which has many alternative names, appears to be a wholly-owned subsidiary of CNPC.
sources: http://tm.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201907/20190702877841.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://oil.in-en.com/html/oil-2866495.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.cnpc.com.cn/en/Turkmenistan/country_index.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

title: Chinese Government provides an RMB 100 million grant for modernization of Turkmenistan's telecommunications network (Linked to project ID#73056)
description: In March 2005, an RMB 100 million contract was signed between Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd. and the Turkmen Ministry of Telecommunications for the supply and deliver of equipment for the modernization of Turkmenistan’s telecommunication network. This contracted included the provision of digital switching equipment with a total capacity to 140,312 lines. According to the Turkmen Ministry of Communications, the Chinese Government financed this a state-of-the-art digital telephone station, ETS-460D, was installed in Ashgabat by Huawei and Turkmen specialists in February 2005. This station provided cellular radio-telephone services in CDMA.The project was linked to a grant project ID#73056 for the training of Turkmen specialists in China, which is also signed during an official visit of Zhang Zhigang, China’s vice minister for commerce (MOFCOM), to the republic, the Ashgabat correspondent of Turkmenistan in 2005.STAFF-NOTE: The Atlantic article states that financing for the CDMA grid was provided "by grants and interest-free loans", while other official sources (reported by media sources) said that the project was financed through a grant. The later was chosen. "Year uncertain" box was checked because it is not clear year this grant was committed to.
sources: https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2012/02/chinese-telecoms-may-be-spying-on-large-numbers-of-foreign-customers/253185/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/e8su1g7o5qt178f/Chinese%20specialists%20help%20install%20new%20digital%20telephone%20station%20in%20Ashgabat%20_%20Turkmenistan.ru.pdf?dl=0, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.turkmenistan.ru/en/node/3866, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.commsupdate.com/articles/2005/03/15/turkmen-government-signs-chy100-million-deal-with-huawei/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://images.sh-itc.net/202002/20200228132540562.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://images.sh-itc.net/201902/20190227095834614.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://fec.mofcom.gov.cn/article/gbdqzn/upload/tukumansitan.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Chinese Government provides interest-free loan to Turkmenistan for purchase of Chinese drilling rigs for natural gas exploration and development
description: During the visit of President of Turkmenistan Gurbanguly Berdimuhamedow to China on July 17 and 18, 2007, the Chinese Government provided Turkmenistan with an interest-free loan for the purchase of Chinese drillings rigs. These rigs were intended to be used for the exploration and development of natural gas fields. STAFF_NOTE: Further loan details are unknown.
sources: http://www.turkmenistan.ru/en/node/5923, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.files.ethz.ch/isn/106328/js09turkmenistanunder.pdf, Academic Journal Article; https://www.files.ethz.ch/isn/106328/js09turkmenistanunder.pdf, Academic Journal Article

title: China Exim Bank 450 Million RMB loan to supply telecommunication equipment to Ministry of Communication (linked to #40214)
description: China Eximbank is providing 450 million RMB for the supply of telecommunications equipment to the Turkmenistan Ministry of Communication. As of 2012, the project was still being implemented, according to a Turkmenistan State Bank Annual Report. This project is part of a committed line of credit worth 650 million RMB to Turkmenistan for communications in 2005 (#40214) along with 200 million RMB export credits for telecommunications in 2006 (#40332). STAFF_NOTE: The original commitment date is unclear. The umbrella project of 650 million RMB was committed in 2005 and the 200 million RMB project was committed in 2006. The year is marked as 2006 to better reflect the transaction amount.

title: China Eximbank provides a 60.6 million USD loan for construction of Ashgabat Glass Factory (Linked to Project ID#40330, #69497)
description: On August 22, 2006, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a $300 million USD preferential export buyer's credit framework agreement with the Government of Turkmenistan (see umbrella project ID#40330). The loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an annual interest rate of 3.0%.On January 30, 2007, China National Machinery Industry Corporation, Capital-Longqji Sci-Tech Co., Ltd, signed a commercial contract with the Government of Turkmenistan for the construction and renovation of the Ashgabat Glass Factory under the USD 300 million preferential export buyer’s credit framework.Then, on November 3-4, 2007, China and Turkmenistan signed for two subsidiary loans with the same terms as the framework agreement: a loan of 60,642,000 USD was allocated for the construction of the Ashgabat Glass Factory, a glass-manufacturing plant (captured by this project) and a loan of 239,358,000 USD for the construction of new facilities and reconstruction of MaryAzot Production Association (captured in project ID#69497). To secure these loans, the Central Bank of Turkmenistan agreed to deposit 50 million USD from the State Fund for Development of the Oil and Gas Industry and Mineral Resources of Turkmenistan.The Ashgabat Glass Factory was located in the northern part of Ashgabat. It was expected to become the largest plant in the region when completed, and was to be fitted with modern equipment and mainly use locally produced raw materials. Additionally, it was expected to produce 5.8 million square meters of glass (4 mm thick), 85 million units of various glass containers, nd 300,000 square meters of double-glazing units, including toned glass units, annually. A silica sand enrichment plant capable of producing 100,000 tons annually was also included in the project. China National Machinery Industry Corporation (Sinomach) and Capital-Lonqji Sci-Tech Co., Ltd were contracted to implement the project. The plant was to be commissioned in February 2009. The entire project was reported to cost $67.38 million USD, so there were likely non-Eximbank financiers. STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese title of the project is 土库曼斯坦玻璃厂建设项目.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=NOVA000020060824e28o0002y&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=BBCCA00020071211e3cb001md&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.cetin.net.cn/cetin2/servlet/cetin/action/HtmlDocumentAction;jsessionid=4FC102D37704901FF631F5521FDB8388?baseid=1&docno=309802, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=DLSTEN0020071109e3b50000a&cat=a&ep=ASI, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=TRENDE0020070129e31t001ry&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.chem.hc360.com/2007/02/0514555186.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=LBA0000020071108e3b5001o0&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.turkmenistan.ru/en/node/4898, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.rferl.org/a/1070758.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.turkmenistan.ru/en/node/5259, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://search.proquest.com/docview/2095209179?pq-origsite=gscholar&fromopenview=true, Academic Journal Article; https://www.dropbox.com/s/77e5y0ofv1zfphk/%E5%9C%9F%E5%BA%93%E6%9B%BC%E6%96%AF%E5%9D%A6--%E4%B8%AD%E5%9B%BD%E5%AF%B9%E5%A4%96%E5%BC%80%E6%94%BE30%E5%91%A8%E5%B9%B4%E5%9B%9E%E9%A1%BE%E5%B1%95.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/c0so9pwet0v5tnt/Turkmenistan%20-%20Retrospective%20of%20the%2030th%20Anniversary%20of%20China%27s%20Opening%20to%20the%20Outside%20World.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China provides a 100 million CNY loan to finance the purchase of Chinese drilling and hoist equipment
description: On July 5-7, 2000, during the visit of Chinese President Jiang Zemin to Turkmenistan, he held talks with Turkmenistan President Niyazov and signed the China-Turkmenistan Joint Declaration. Chinese Minister of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Shi Guangsheng signed a framework agreement with Turkmenistan's Deputy Prime Minister Kandymov on China's provision of a 100 million yuan concessional loan to Turkmenistan. In 2000, China loaned 100 million RMB to Turkmenistan to finance the purchase of Chinese drilling and hoist equipment for the Turkmenneft and Turkmengas, which are state-owned enterprises.
sources: https://www.rferl.org/a/1347027.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.gasandoil.com/news/2004/01/ntc40439, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://web.archive.org/web/20100720222129/http://politics.people.com.cn/GB/8198/158801/158803/9517301.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
